channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Covid-19: 'Very few' Covid hospital patients had two jabs, NHS boss says
item.description: NHS boss Chris Hopson adds it's "incredibly striking" how busy hospitals are with non-Covid patients.

item.title: Boris Johnson marries Carrie Symonds at Westminster Cathedral
item.description: Downing Street says the wedding took place on Saturday afternoon "in a small ceremony".

item.title: Holding on to hope during India’s Covid disaster
item.description: The BBC's Nikita Mandhani reflects on her personal experience of the second wave in India.

item.title: Plans for new national flagship to promote 'best of British'
item.description: The government plans to build a successor to Britannia in the UK, at a reported cost of about £200m.

item.title: Covid-19: 'Very few' patients are fully vaccinated, and bars struggle for staff
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Sunday morning.

item.title: Belarus: Hundreds join global solidarity protests
item.description: Crowds call for the release of an activist who was arrested when his flight was grounded in Minsk.

item.title: South Western Ambulance Service declares 'critical incident'
item.description: South Western Ambulance Service blames "extreme pressures" for extended wait times for patients.

item.title: Senior MP demands answers for leaseholders
item.description: Clive Betts asks why guidance for leaseholders selling or remortgaging flats is not being followed.

item.title: Partner of Tory peer's son held over Belize death
item.description: Jasmine Hartin, the partner of Lord Ashcroft's son, was discovered near the body of a police officer.

item.title: Brazil: Protesters blame Bolsonaro for Covid crisis
item.description: Thousands of people angry at the slow rollout of vaccines took to the streets in cities across Brazil.

item.title: North Korea says orphan children volunteering on mines and farms
item.description: State news reports the children want "to repay even just a millionth of the love the party showed".

item.title: How opera helped me come out as trans
item.description: Adrian Angelico is one of the few trans male opera singers in the world.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: PM 'weds in secret' and Wuhan lab leak 'feasible'
item.description: The front pages are dominated by the 30-guest wedding of Boris Johnson and Carrie Symonds.

item.title: Dogs rehomed: ‘She went from a defeated dog, to a great pet’
item.description: For dogs like June, a new home is a lifesaver - but more animals may need new homes post-lockdown.

item.title: Covid: Teaching post-Covid patients to breathe again
item.description: A tai chi teacher found he was contacted by patients during the pandemic.

item.title: CCTV shows Khan before he carried out the attack
item.description: CCTV and other footage shown at the inquest shows Usman Khan before he carried out the attack.

item.title: Piccadilly 1965: How six Indian friends found their feet in the UK
item.description: One day in 1965 Praful Patel heard five men talking Gujarati in London's Central YMCA - they quickly became close friends.

item.title: Samantha Azzopardi: Australia's notorious con artist sentenced for child theft
item.description: Authorities are baffled by the "bizarre crime" of a serial con artist who has travelled the world.

item.title: Jeremy Clarkson reveals 'heartache' filming farming TV series
item.description: The Grand Tour star is swapping cars for tractors as he embarks on his first solo TV show for Amazon.

item.title: Buying a pink NFT cat was a crypto nightmare
item.description: Trying to own a virtual feline proves to be an exhausting and expensive process.

item.title: How Ben Crump became America's go-to civil rights lawyer
item.description: When families lose a loved one in a police shooting, more often than not Ben Crump gets a call. Why is he the go-to man?

item.title: Covid and jobs: Why are hospitality workers leaving the industry?
item.description: While employers hunt for chefs, waitresses and bar staff, some workers have called time on the sector.

item.title: Thomas Tuchel's masterclass leaves Pep Guardiola in despair
item.description: The story of Chelsea's Champions League showpiece cast both managers as its central characters.

item.title: After a 32-year battle for justice, what is Hillsborough's legacy?
item.description: As the collapse of the last criminal trial marks the end of a long legal road, Judith Moritz asks what the legacy of Britain’s worst sports disaster is.

item.title: Champions League final: Kai Havertz & N'Golo Kante key for Chelsea against Man City
item.description: Like N'Golo Kante, Chelsea's Kai Havertz had a key role in Thomas Tuchel's tactical plan to win Saturday's Champions League final, says ex-Manchester City midfielder Michael Brown.

item.title: 'I made the best selection to win the game' - but did Guardiola get it wrong?
item.description: Pep Guardiola was pragmatic following Manchester City's Champions League final defeat to Chelsea, but was it one tinker too many by the City boss?

item.title: Chelsea beat Man City to win Champions League for second time
item.description: Chelsea win the Champions League for second time after beating Manchester City in a thrilling final in Porto.

item.title: 'Boxing must learn from this' - Warren's response to Joshua v Fury 'mess'
item.description: Boxing needs to learn from the "mess" that saw Anthony Joshua's heavyweight unification fight with Tyson Fury cancelled, Frank Warren says.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over-18s can now have the vaccine in Wales and Northern Ireland, while over-30s can get it in England and Scotland.

item.title: Does the UK have highest Covid death toll in Europe?
item.description: The total is the largest but for deaths per 100,000 people the UK is no longer top.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid vaccine update: Those that work - and the others on the way
item.description: Covid vaccination campaigns are under way in the UK and across the world.

item.title: Man with speech aid uses new Yorkshire accent after appeal
item.description: Richie Cottingham, who has cerebral palsy, used local voices to replace his American speech aid.

item.title: George Floyd: Should we stop sharing videos of black trauma?
item.description: A video of George Floyd's last moments was watched and shared by millions.

item.title: Super-rare orange lobsters rescued from Leicester shop display
item.description: A shopper spotted the bright pair, thought to be as rare as one in 30 million, at Makro in Leicester.

item.title: Whatever happened to Peter the Armenian cook?
item.description: The search for the mysterious man behind a cult Edinburgh restaurant who disappeared a decade ago.

item.title: Forced adoptions: Former MP Ann Keen recalls no dignity and no say
item.description: Ann Keen says she was humiliated and forced to give up her baby at a Swansea mother and baby home.

item.title: Children tell of neglect, filth and fear in US asylum camps
item.description: The BBC has uncovered allegations of cold temperatures, sickness, lice and abuse, through a series of interviews with children and staff at US detention camps for children.

item.title: Rafael Nadal: The 'tough love' that shaped a 20-time Grand Slam champion
item.description: From 'scaredy cat' to a 'raging bull', Rafael Nadal's transformation into a true tennis great has a lot to do with one man in particular.

item.title: Martin Bashir inquiry: Diana, the reporter and the BBC
item.description: The full story of how the BBC's Martin Bashir got his 1995 interview with Princess Diana - and what happened next.
